Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Analysis of longitudinal multiscale data in immunological bioinformatics - Feature selection, graphical models, and structure identification
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to develop a system of statistical analysis tools to tackle several important challenges in analysis of complex bioinformatics data, which involves a variety of response variables and tens of thousands independent variables. The interest often lies in identifying the key independent variables associated with the response variables, and understanding such associations as well as the interactions among the independent variables.

The extreme magnitude and complexity of bioinformatics data have posed serious challenges for data analysis. To overcome these challenges, we propose (i) to systematically and properly integrate multi-scale data before we can apply our novel modeling and analysis methods since the data we explore are collected by numerous independent studies at phenotypic, cellular, protein, and genetic levels with information from very different time and dimension scales; (ii) to develop feature screening criteria for a mixed type of longitudinal data using the combination of correlation tests in bivariate longitudinal regression models and the Benjamini-Hochberg-Yekutieli procedure, (iii) to develop graphical models that allow the variables being a mix of continuous and discrete longitudinal variables, with the nodes representing variables and each edge indicating the dependence of the two relevant variables conditional on the other variables; and (iv) to investigate the functioning form of each predictor by resorting to the data themselves under the framework of a mixed effects regression model with a continuous or discrete response and a high dimensional vector of predictors, with the resulting procedure allowing a user to simultaneously determine the form of each predictor effect to be zero, linear or nonlinear.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: The objective of this project is to develop a system of statistical analysis tools to tackle several important challenges in analysis of complex (longitudinal) bioinformatics data, which involves a variety of response variables and tens of thousands independent variables. Seven publications on peer-reviewed mathematical/statistical and IEEE journals have been resulted from this project: i) one for graphical modeling of longitudinal omics data; ii) three for structural identifiability analysis of graphical model; iii) two for feature screening and classification of time series data; iv) and one for COVID-19 pandemic modeling. In particular, the PI has developed the very first effective and scalable structure inference technique for large-scale networks with millions of unknown parameters based on longitudinal omics data. To account for the existence of latent variables, feedback loops, self-loops and disturbance correlations in many real networks, the PI further investigated the structural identifiability problem of static and dynamic graphical models. Such work is also the first of its kind. The PI also extended his research work to time series data, particularly the feature screening and classification problems. The PI also applied his modeling technique to investigate the COVID-19 pandemic, and the resulted publication has been selected by a peer-reviewed journal and the American Statistical Association Joint Statistical Meeting 2020 for press release. Broader impact: two PhD students (one male and one female) received related training under this support. Two undergraduate students were attracted to do summer research program related to machine learning of big biomedical data, and after that, one of the undergraduate students applied for our PhD program and successfully enrolled. With the support of this project, the PI has further incorporated the related research problems into both statistical and data science course development. His courses usually involve more than 30 PHD/master students.
